summary_variants.short_answer: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist and chemist who pioneered research on radioactivity and won two Nobel Prizes.
summary_variants.kid_friendly: Marie Curie studied tiny, invisible things called atoms and discovered new elements. She won two big science prizes for her work.
summary_variants.standard: Marie Curie (1867–1934) was a Polish-born physicist and chemist who moved to France, discovered the elements polonium and radium, and helped establish the theory of radioactivity. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and remains the only person to win Nobel Prizes in two different scientific fields.
summary_variants.expert_notes: Discuss her isolation of radium, development of mobile X-ray units during World War I, and enduring impact on nuclear physics and medical imaging.
